channel.title: Camera Algorithm

item.title: Camera Algorithm
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

There’s a minimapInt (3?) in srcAllDummiesRemoved which tells you the angle of the minimap, ranging between 0 and 2000.

Put this in your client, it could come in handy:

aTextDrawingArea_1270.method385(0xffff00, "camera [x/y/z/cX/cY]: "+xCameraPos+" / "+yCameraPos+" / "+zCameraPos+" / "+xCameraCurve+" / "+yCameraCurve, 262, 4);

Read full topic

item.title: Camera Algorithm
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

edit: oh shit i did it again, i managed to fill a whole page with text,
i guess it must be boring to read, but at least try, it does have some good stuff down there…

[quote=“ruler, post:20, topic:209666”]I am talking about the values in a un-modified client, where the client sets the varibles.
changing the value may have many implications.
changeing the varible out of the intened range may yeild incorrect behaviors. Value overflows, rounding errors, etc.[/quote]

that tool isnt about moving it out of bounds, its about controlling each variable separately,
think about it logically, you have two directions to go with your keyboard, up-down, and left-right
and you have to control 5 variables with them,
obviously, they are combined,

when you press the up-down buttons, the pitch is not the only thing that changes, and Ollie’s diagram seems to show this, but its wrong in that way

i think not many of you have actually tried that camera man app, you probably think “oh I’m high and mighty, i dont need to entertain myself with this nooby activity”
but you should, those pictures i uploaded show nothing compared to what its like, you need to see how the client behaves under those circumstances, otherwise you’ll just screw up in discussions like these,

iv drawn some diagrams for you, to demonstrate how many variable change

this is how ill show the camera, as a kind of torch, the green shaded area is the cone-of-light where it can “see”

consider this situation:
the first position is when the camera is looking straight at you, like you pressed the “down” button
the second position is when the camera is above you, like you pressed “up”

there are two axis, z and x,

let X1 be the displacement from x axis, or cameraX
let Z1 be the displacement from z axis, or cameraZ
let theta2 be the angle between z-axis and camera, or cameraPitch

iv drawn a little diagram for you of how it changes when you press “up” key

as you can see, when you press “up”, the cameraX rises so it goes over your player and looks down, its is now X2
the cameraZ rises, so you are looking from higher then your player, its now Z2
the cameraPitch falls, so you look more down, instead of long, its now theta2

you have to separate the variables, you cant just think “oh, pressing up key makes cameraPitch fall”
you cant control 5 variables with 2 controls, the runescape client combines them, and tricks your little mind into thinking its very simple

if you use my program, you’ll see the effect each has, and understand it better,
you can make the pitch higher when you in camera position 2,

and please forget your ridiculous idea of cameraYaw being something to do with the minimap compass angle,

oh by the way, as for the camera variables going out of bounds, thats just for show for those screenshots,
those screenshots really dont make it move, and you cant know what its like just by looking at them,
the real McCoy is when you change one variable at a time, thats the whole point.

as for the rounding errors and overflows, they dont happen if you’re careful
and if they do happen, the game crashes,

the rendering engine in the client is very… emm… whats the word… can take new changes well, i guess extensible
when you change the values, the client handles it fine,

have you ever played those quests with cutscenes?
dont they zoom in and out, how else do they do that without making the variables go “out of bounds”

Read full topic

item.title: Camera Algorithm
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

Ollie:

ignore vbcoderx, he doesnt know what he is talking about.

You flame vbcoderx for first bring it up; and now you offer the exact same explanation.

[quote=“Ollie, post:23, topic:209666”]ruler, there are X, Y and Z intersects of the player, the roll and pitch are the height and rotation of the camera

[/quote]
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tait-Bryan_angles

For a craft moving in the positive x direction, with the right side corresponding to the positive y direction, and the vertical underside corresponding to the positive z direction, these three angles are individually called roll, pitch and yaw.
The camera is not moving in this respect.
en.wikipedia.org

Euler angles

The Euler angles are three angles introduced by Leonhard Euler to describe the orientation of a rigid body with respect to a fixed coordinate system. They can also represent the orientation of a mobile frame of reference in physics or the orientation of a general basis in 3-dimensional linear algebra. Any orientation can be achieved by composing three elemental rotations, i.e. rotations about the axes of a coordinate system. Euler angles can be defined by three of these rotations. They can also ...

The Euler angles were developed by Leonhard Euler to describe the orientation of a rigid body (a body in which the relative position of all its points is constant

…

The intersection of the xy and the XY coordinate planes is called the line of nodes (N).
α is the angle between the x-axis and the line of nodes.
β is the angle between the z-axis and the Z-axis.
γ is the angle between the line of nodes and the X-axis.


therefore my orignal definition stands.

Read full topic

item.title: Camera Algorithm
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

I am talking about the values in a un-modified client, where the client sets the varibles.
changing the value may have many implications.
changeing the varible out of the intened range may yeild incorrect behaviors. Value overflows, rounding errors, etc.
Client may have multiple location for the varible, etc.
You have this thing called block client control.

I dont see a camera pitch/yaw in these fields.

import java.awt.Graphics;

import impsoft.bots.ColorBot;
import impsoft.scripting.ibot.interfaces.AutoPaint;
import impsoft.scripting.types.ColorScript;
import impsoft.utils.general.Worm;

public class CameraPrinter extends ColorScript implements AutoPaint {
   Worm CameraX, CameraZ, CameraY, CameraIntersectPlayer, CameraCompass;

   public CameraPrinter(ColorBot b) {
      super(b);
      try {
         CameraX = new Worm(getColorBot().theClientClassLoader, "ae.L", getHandler());
         CameraZ = new Worm(getColorBot().theClientClassLoader, "pc.v", getHandler());
         CameraY = new Worm(getColorBot().theClientClassLoader, "kj.h", getHandler());
         CameraIntersectPlayer = new Worm(getColorBot().theClientClassLoader, "ie.Z", getHandler());
         CameraCompass = new Worm(getColorBot().theClientClassLoader, "cb.i", getHandler());
      } catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
         e.printStackTrace();
      }
   }

   public void script() throws InterruptedException, Exception {
      sleep(1000000);
   }

   public void paint(Graphics g) {
      g.drawString("Camera Position X = " + CameraX.getIntValue(), 20, 20);
      g.drawString("Camera Position Y =  " + CameraY.getIntValue(), 20, 40);
      g.drawString("Camera Position Z =  " + CameraZ.getIntValue(), 20, 60);
      g.drawString("Camera Intersect Player " + CameraIntersectPlayer.getIntValue() + " Angle "
            + (((double) CameraIntersectPlayer.getIntValue() / 2040 * 360)), 20, 80);
      g.drawString("Real Compass " + CameraCompass.getIntValue() + " Angle " + (((double) CameraCompass.getIntValue() / 2040 * 360)), 20,
            100);
   }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Camera Algorithm
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

pitch, roll, and yaw are just the euler angle representations, they could use matrices or quaternions if they felt like it

are the ‘camera curves’ the precomputed sine/cosine arrays? i cant possibly think of any other “curve”

yakman alluded to a compass offset, this has existed since rsc, as has the scale and (i forget the third variable involved). i believe ollie mentioned them and explained some in another thread

yakman:

Class26.cameraPlayerZIntercept

if he were to name it something like that, it would be due to not understanding what the field represents (it is also a ghastly name :\ )

[quote=“Unhandled, post:15, topic:209666”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=276135.msg2259181#msg2259181 date=1212477124]
on a scale of one to ten of being a twat, ruler has cleared the bar and gone straight to 50
[/quote]
At least he isn’t too arrogant to actually post something informative.[/quote]
ask an intelligent question and you will hopefully get an intelligent answer, cry like a bitch and you will get flamed

item.title: Camera Algorithm
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

why dont you see camera pitch/yaw?
thats obviously what it is,

so according to you, it should be called
Class26.cameraPlayerZIntercept
Class48.trueCompassAngle

when you use my little camera man app to change to change cameraYaw, or “true compass angle”, the minimap compass doesnt actually change, so that variable obviously has nothing to do with the compass
look at this picture, according the main screen camera, i am facing north, but according to the minimap compass, i am facing west

you cant just call it an angle, because there are many different planes it moves in,
you have to say “the angle in the horizontal plane”, “the angle in the verticle plane”

also, i had a whole thread filled with camera pitching and yawing, why didnt you bring up this issue there?
i named them that because i believe its a better name then “cameraCurveX/Y”

edit: i dont see roll either, you cant roll the camera as far as i can tell (without messing around a lot), its pitch and yaw only

Read full topic
